title: 103_s1049
content: The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" recognizes the scientific and environmental significance of Lechuguilla Cave and other caves in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. It aims to protect these caves from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" defines key terms such as cave protection area and Secretary. It also clarifies that terms not specified have the same meaning as in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993 withdraws approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described in a map filed in April 1993. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description of the lands withdrawn under subsection (a) and file the description and a map with the relevant committees in Congress. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description of the lands withdrawn under subsection (a) for public inspection. The public lands will be managed by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management in accordance with the Federal Land Policy. The Bureau of Land Management manages public lands in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and other applicable laws. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary shall not permit new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within the lands withdrawn under section 4 to prevent adverse impacts on cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The Secretary prohibits new drilling on mineral or geothermal leases within Carlsbad Caverns National Park to protect cave resources. This prohibition will last until a decision is made on the drilling proposal or for 12 months after the enactment of the Act. During the specified period, the Secretary will negotiate with lease holders for termination or restrictions on activities to protect Lechuguilla Cave on public lands withdrawn under section 4(a). The Secretary will negotiate agreements to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, with consideration for oil and gas resources that owners will not be allowed to recover. If no agreement is reached for a lease, the Secretary will take necessary actions after the specified period. The Secretary will take appropriate steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, which may include acquiring lands or interests for management under federal regulations. The Secretary will manage the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 and other relevant laws. Cooperation with the State of New Mexico and other landowners in the cave protection area may be sought to implement use restrictions for further protection. The Secretary will manage the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park and the lands within the cave protection area. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park based on relevant scientific analysis. Access limitations may be imposed to safeguard these resources. The Secretary may limit access to lands within the cave protection area and prohibit removal of mineral, geological, or cave resources, unless permitted for scientific purposes. If existing laws are insufficient to protect Lechuguilla Cave or other significant cave resources, the Secretary will take necessary steps. The Secretary will inform relevant committees about additional authority needed for lands within the cave protection area. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under existing laws, such as the Tucker Act. The Act does not impact the ability to seek compensation under existing laws like the Tucker Act in connection with any action seeking compensation from the United States.
